habitat_description:
Southwest:
This California endemic Dipodomys species is found from Suisun Bay through the San Joaquin Valley below elevations of 3000 feet, in interior valleys to the coast at Morro Bay and Santa Barbara County (Grinnell 1922, Hall 1981, Kelt 1988, Williams et al. 1993). This species prefers loose, well-drained soils through which it can construct it's sometimes elaborate burrows, entrances of which are often located beneath brush and boulders (Wilson and Ruff 1999). They are common in valley foothill hardwood and mixed conifer early successional habitats, annual grasslands, coastal scrub and montane chapparal where they feed on grains, forbs and seasonal grasses ([Brylski et al. 2008] based on Zeiner et al. 1990).
